title: Supervisor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI)
Interview Descriptions: One interview with the office supervisor and manager and they go over situations with you. Every question deals with how you'd handle these situations with an emphasis on explaining your process.
Interview Questions: If you come into work and it is just you and a new hire student, how would you handle an overflowing trash area, a messy line, and missing food?

title: HR Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Easy and friendly people, asked why I would be a good fit and to explain my experiences. Shared what they had learned. Very easy going and kind to speak with
Interview Questions: My experience and history with similar skills

title: Cloud Architect Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: The interview lasted about 30 minutes. I did not get asked any tough technical questions. It was mostly focused on behavioral questions about my past experiences. I would suggest brush up your resume and prepare to answer anything based on that.
Interview Questions: How would you communicate a technical problem to your manager who might not necessarily be from a technical background?

title: Laboratory Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI)
Interview Descriptions: The first interview was with two PIs related to the Immunology Lab. The second interview was with the PI of the lab I would have been working with. Both were over Zoom with about a 15-30 minute duration.
Interview Questions: Interviewers asked about my work history and where I see myself in five years.

title: Housekeeping Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: 1. Meeting at the union south, time slot available during summer 2. daily working time confirm 3. training course that needs to be done 4. wage confirm 5. ice cream tickets available
Interview Questions: do you have previous experience about housekeeping in hotel?

title: Research Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: I met with a panel of interviewers, including my supervisor, an HR representative, a leader of a similar group, and others in similar roles. We had a standard set of questions assessing qualifications for the position and previous research experience.
Interview Questions: Describe a situation in which you failed, and what you learned from the experience.

title: GIS Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison in Mar 2023
Interview Descriptions: Virtual panel interview on MS teams with structured questions, the interview was around an hour long with time at the end to ask additional questions here are some extra words to satisfy glassdoor.
Interview Questions: What is your experience with web GIS?

title: PhD Student Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Easy if you did undergrad there. Everyone in the program had been at Wisconsin in undergrad as well. I believe there was an essay about ethics and some books to read. Grading by a well structured rubric.
Interview Questions: Why do you want to be a part of this program?

title: Career Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: The interview I had was virtual and about 30 minutes long. I just had to meet with one person who determined whether or not I was a fit for the job.
Interview Questions: They asked me why did I want to be a career advisor and why did I want to work there rather than somewhere else?

title: Research Intern Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Very straight forward. I was asked to talk about myself and my experiences as well as goals and ambitions. We discussed about what the project I will be involved in revolves around and briefly elaborated what my role in the lab is.
Interview Questions: Why do you want this position?

title: Executive Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: Extremely slow with the entire process. If you are not selected you may never have a final decision shared with you. It entirely depends on the unit/department/school you interview with as to whether you receive communications.
Interview Questions: Give us an example of a time . . . you had to deal with a difficult situation/person.

title: Marketing Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Jan 2023
Interview Descriptions: I did this interview on zoom interviews. The interviewers are very friendly and allowed for back-and-forth conversions. The questions were pretty generic like What are your weaknesses, Tell me about yourself.
Interview Questions: Tell Me About Yourself What Are your strengths What are 2-3 weaknesses you need to improve?

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: The interview was very professional. The interviewers knew their domain very well and were sincerely interested in learning more about me and my experience. They sound like a good organization to work for.
Interview Questions: Tell us about yourself and your background.

title: HR Generalist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: 4 panel interviews with different groups lasting approximately 4 hours. Most of the questions were very straightforward, but the process was a little exhausting. Was via Zoom the entire time. I dressed in business formal but it felt like too much.
Interview Questions: What laws might you have to be aware of in this position?

title: House Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Resume submission portion; Call backs received an interview. Interview was set up as a panel, where previous house fellows and a supervisor asked you questions relating to your relevant qualifications, madison’s DEI efforts, and why you’d be a good fit.
Interview Questions: Do you have a job now? How would you ensure enough time for this job next year?

title: Administrative Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Usually, if you do not supervise employees, you might only need to do 1-2 rounds of interviews.  They can range from 30 to 1 hour, depending on who is sitting on your review committee. I would encourage asking questions.
Interview Questions: Can you provide an example of a time your managed several projects at the same time?

title: Support Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: It was a really laid back conversation with one of the student team leads, and the staff supervisor. They asked me fairly generic questions about how I interact with customers, how I deal with difficult situations and people, and how I problem solve.
Interview Questions: How have you dealt with difficult situations at work? Have you ever disagreed with a coworker?

title: Tech Support Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Interview was awkward and was not contacted and ghosted over email afterwards. Manager seemed to interject and be disorganized.  Was overqualified for the position and getting paid less and was still not offered the job
Interview Questions: What experience do you have with IT support

title: Business Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison in Jun 2022
Interview Descriptions: This was a pretty standard Business Analyst interview, with pretty common questions regarding methodologies, requirements gathering processes, and project management functions. There were 3 individuals on the hiring committee one of which was the supervisor for the position.
Interview Questions: How would you go about eliciting business requirements, and what tools or technologies would you use to assist you?

title: Accountant 1 Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Application response was quick and an interview was scheduled soon after. Interview consisted of 1 round with a panel of five department members. The interview included short introductions, interviewer questions, interviewee questions and next steps.
Interview Questions: Q: What software and programs do you have experience with that would be relevant to this position?

title: Clinical Research Coordinator II Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in May 2022
Interview Descriptions: One phone call as an initial interview and a second interview that was with the full team I would be working with. The first call was about 30 minutes and the second was around 45 minutes
Interview Questions: In the past when a coworker made a mistake, how did you handle it?

title: Intern Interview
Application Type: The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Apr 2022
Interview Descriptions: They reach out through email for you to schedule an interview based on when you are available. Then you come in to the office to interview. They will call you back if you got the job
Interview Questions: How do you manage multiple things at once

title: Student Caller Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: It was fairly straightforward. Not difficult. Would recommend to anyone who is looking for some extra skills and money before they graduate. Great people and great team. You really learn some good skills.
Interview Questions: What is your major in school?

title: Career Coach Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Mar 2022
Interview Descriptions: 4 person panel interview, AUDIO only. No introductions, 5 questions. Very impersonal and wasn’t able to get a feel for the people/department at all. The panel didn’t respond to anything, just went on to the next question. No way to build rapport, felt like I was in a strange monologue without an audience.
Interview Questions: What is you approach to coaching?

title: Researcher Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Feb 2022
Interview Descriptions: the phone interview was very easy. they asked technical questions. But among 5 interviews only one PI invited me to go to an onsite interview. Most positions already have candidates. maybe just they need to post the job.
Interview Questions: why do you want to leave your current position?

title: Student Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Jan 2022
Interview Descriptions: Interview was scheduled less than a week from applying and was conducted online and had only one round of interviews. Was offered the job on the spot and I accepted it.
Interview Questions: How would you handle a customer who is getting impatient?

title: Project Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 5 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions:
1st interview: 15 minute zoom interview with director and 3 other Project Managers
2nd interview: 1 hour interview with 4 previous people and additional staff. 20 minute Q&A with staff m.
Interview Questions: Previous experience, why are you interested in this role, dealing with coworker / management when you don’t agree with them, dealing with a complicated customer, etc.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Prepare well for the questions that you can think of.  the Meet the recruiter, two times interview, each last for 30 min. Then you just wait for their response do decide.
Interview Questions: Why you want to apply for this position

title: Clinical Data Coordinator Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Nov 2021
Interview Descriptions: Easy and efficient online application. One on one phone call with hiring manager, followed by 3 video interviews (first with hiring manager, second with additional managers and 3rd with the entire team).
Interview Questions: Why are you looking to change careers?

title: Accountant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 4 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Nov 2021
Interview Descriptions: There were 2 panel interviews with a group of 5 each, the first was via zoom and second was in an in person interview. Both interview were not difficult. The panel was friendly and approachable.
Interview Questions: Name a time you had to work with a challenging coworker. How did you navigate the situation

title: Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: There were two rounds of interviews, first with two direct reports above this position, the next with the team. The second included a 30 minute writing exercise that was easy. Once I got the first interview, communication was quick and I knew what to expect every step of the way.
Interview Questions: What are your career goals?

title: Peer Advisor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: 30-minute video interview with two super nice ISS staff.  They are very easy to talk to and made it a good interview experience. The questions are not hard and they would try to make you relax too.
Interview Questions: Your experience working with non-native speakers.

title: Student Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 days. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Oct 2021
Interview Descriptions: The meeting process was really straight forward  and friendly. They made sure all my questions were answered and introduced themselves really nicely. They made sure that I understood the job really well before they started with the questions which was really nice.
Interview Questions: What sort of previous experience I had helping a friend with a tech issue?

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: The professor introduced his lab and research in his office. He gave me a lab tour, met his lab members, then asked a few questions about my goals in the future.
Interview Questions: Asked about the past academic background and current interest

title: SOAR Peer Advisor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: They offered group interviews and if you could not make it they would set up a private interview. Questions were very simple, mostly "what would you do in this situation" questions.
Interview Questions: What would you do if a fellow employee was saying/acting inappropriately with a student?

title: Associate Professor Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: A competitive process, however if you have the necessary qualifications and background it shouldn't be an issue. Being a fellow badger also helped me. Recommended to anyone who has previous experience in the industry
Interview Questions: What is one thing that drives you forward?

title: Production Cook Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions: My interview was over the phone due to the pandemic. I was asked about my basic food service knowledge and given a few different potential scenarios i may come across in the kitchen and explain how i would overcome them.
Interview Questions: How would you teach a student worker to make macaroni and cheese.

title: Adjunct Professor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Milwaukee, WI) in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions: Short, inadequate, not much info. Was hired with no guidelines. Given wrong course to teach but they only realized it 3 weeks in. Will never work for them again! Very disorganized!
Interview Questions: When I could start working.

title: Graduate Teaching Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Jul 2021
Interview Descriptions: I interviewed for a TA job in the Math Department. The interview process was straightforward. The interviewer asked me to solve a couple of Calculus problems. Then he asked behavioral questions to see if I could handle teaching 60 students in a class. Then we talked about salary and ended with a question from me which was a brief about the working culture as a TA.
Interview Questions:
What does an exponential graph look like?
What is the mean value theorem?
Have you had any teaching experience before?

title: Project Manager Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Zoom interview with two staff members; I tried to ask questions about the project but neither of the staff were terribly knowledgeable on the subject. Ultimately I did not move forward in the interview process and felt that for the best.
Interview Questions: Why did you apply for this position?

title: Marketing Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Very professional, yet welcoming throughout. From the initial emails inviting me to apply, to the interview itself, everyone was welcoming, and even though I didn't get the job, received a personal email from the manager afterwards. Rare to leave an interview for a job you didn't get and have zero sting, yet WFAA did it.
Interview Questions: Please name a previous work experience you think would help you succeed in this role.

title: Faculty Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Zoom meeting 1:1 with the Director. Very easygoing and casual questions about experience, the vibe was relaxed and remote. Most questions were about logistics and scheduling with a few scenarios about past teaching experiences.
Interview Questions: Describe a time you disagreed with a student and how you handled it

title: Student Data Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 3 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in May 2021
Interview Descriptions: They first set up a 20 minute phone interview with someone from HR. Then I had an hour long virtual interview with two employees I would be working with. Both were low stress.
Interview Questions: How has your coursework prepared you for a data analytics job?

title: Student Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Pretty decent, mostly behavioral interview questions. Talked about managing priorities and stuff like that. Also about some hard skills i might have related to project management and data analysis. It was over the phone with the project manager
Interview Questions: Tell me a little bit more about yourself

title: Assistant Professor, Tenure Track Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Initial phone interview followed by two-day in-person interview.  Phone interview was one hour and consisted of approximately five questions. Also given the opportunity to ask questions at the end.  In-person interview consisted of multiple short meetings.
Interview Questions: What do you see as the grand challenges in your field?

title: Advisor Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Mar 2021
Interview Descriptions: Applied online and heard back from via email that I  had a 30 minute phone screen. Then I was notified again via email that I was selected for a 2 hour final round interview. This interview was broken down into 3 different meetings with several different people in the office.
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time you had to accomplish a task with little or confusing instructions.

title: COVID TESTER Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: She was very patient and kind. she asked proactive questions and I enjoyed conversing with he. Come prepared with questions about the job and if you are professional, it will go well.
Interview Questions: Q: What is a time you had to lead a project on your own under the advising of a mentor?

title: Associate University Relations Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Straightforward interview process without any obscure questions or unexpected requests. I felt the questions were fair and the interviewees were open to answering my questions about the position as well.
Interview Questions: Describe a time when a project went past deadline and what you did to rectify the delay.

title: New Grad Nurse Residency Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: The interview process happened over the phone. They asked a lot of behavioral questions, and "what would you do if" questions. I thought it went really well, and it last about 45 minutes!
Interview Questions: Tell me about a time when you went above and beyond for a client?

title: Digital Marketing Intern Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Feb 2021
Interview Descriptions: Director and HR are very nice and easygoing. They are interested in my creativity and previous campaigns. Basically just telling them what I've done before and what I can bring to the team.
Interview Questions: Questions were all about my previous internship experience and ask me to design a new social media plan

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: meeting with lab manager and talk to professor directly. Professor asked my background experience and degree. It was great to talk to him. He is super nice to talk to.
Interview Questions: Are you a hard working peroson?

title: Payroll Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions:
Normal process - phone interview then in person 4-5 people attended 
Varies accounting questions and description of job 
Questions scenario based and qualifications based. 
If you have experience in the job related field than the interview is normal. Parking is a problem in campus
Interview Questions: They asked basic accounting and payroll question and my experience

title: Financial Specialist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Mostly concerned about personality fit in the office environment.  There wasn't any technical based questions that covered skillsets going to be needed, strictly focused on how you would gel with coworkers.
Interview Questions: What types of people do you work poorly with?

title: Associate Microbiologist Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: I met with the section supervisor and section head for an in-person interview (this was pre-covid). We discussed my experience and the expectations for the position, as well as general questions that would evaluate me as a good fit within the group. It was a positive experience overall.
Interview Questions: What laboratory experience did I have?

title: Undergraduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through an employee referral. The process took 3 days. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Dec 2020
Interview Descriptions: One interview session with the lab manager after an email thread, hired under employee recommendation and was asked for s resume but no cover letter. Interview was clear and delineated lab expectations overall
Interview Questions: My reason for applying, previous experience, and hopes for the job.

title: Administration Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison in Dec 2020
Interview Descriptions: Series of interviews conducted by a panel of 6-9 employees at various levels within the University - to include peers, direct reports and hiring manager.  All interviews were conducted virtually.
Interview Questions: Questions were all designed to have the candidate provide specific situations related to the topic at hand.

title: Marketing Manager Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: There was a ohone interview followed by an in-person interview that included a group presentation on a fictional marketing strategy you prepared-- and Q&A afterwards. Then met with individual team members.
Interview Questions:
Q: How would you segment your marketing strategy?

Q:  Why UW-Madison?

Q: What is a scenario at your current job where you had to push back on someone?

title: Procurement Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Quick - questions very behavioral based. Open to candidates who are willing to learn and are motivated by that in order to reach success. Two interviewers (one main, one sat in observing).
Interview Questions: How would your coworkers at prior jobs describe you?

title: Nurse Resident Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Starts with online application and a personal goal statement. Then a 1 hour difficult phone interview with behavioral based questions and questions regarding the top 3 units you chose. Then if you get through that round, a 1 hour long in person interview with one unit. 8 standard behavioral questions with nurse manager and nurse educator for the floor. Relaxed atmosphere. Took 3 weeks to get back to me.
Interview Questions: Described a time where you failed? How did you handle it?

title: Master's In Business Analytics Program Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 1 day. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Apr 2020
Interview Descriptions: The interview process took place during 2020 so everything was virtual. It consisted of a few video interview questions and then I had some time to respond. Be mindful of the time you had and make sure to look at the camera.
Interview Questions: Tell me about yourself, what did you learn this past year

title: Graduate Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: The interview was similar to other graduate school interviews, multiple interviews with different professors, lunch and dinner with current students, etc.. Heard back relatively soon after the interview and accepted the position.
Interview Questions: Fine

title: Web Developer Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: One on one interview. Interview question was easy. It only process for a week, then I got offer. Overall experience was good and easy. It was nice to practice before you apply for real job after graduate.
Interview Questions: Which course did you enjoy the most?

title: Student Worker Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: I applied via online and then I got some email about the details of job position. So, I asked to have an interview. The interview was 1:1. It was about my experience, personality, and availability of time.
Interview Questions:
Do you have work experience?
What's your advantages of being a team member?

title: Program Analyst Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison in Jan 2020
Interview Descriptions: Multiple step process, with phone interview, in person interview, and presentation.  Phone interview for 60 minutes, full day for in person interviews and presentation. You must enter at least 30 words. You must enter at least 30 words. You must enter at least 30 words.
Interview Questions: What are your biggest strengths.

title: Research Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: I applied for an RA position at a psychology lab. They arranged an in-person interview with me after one week. A graduate student and the lab manager interviewed me. Overall a semi-formal interview process.
Interview Questions: Why did you apply to our lab？

title: Postdoctoral Research Associate Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: One to one interview with the professor. The questions were focused on my previous work experience and background. The interview experience was great. Very technical interview. Plenty of opportunity for discussion.
Interview Questions: What are your experiences related to biological treatment of wastewater?

title: Research Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Nov 2019
Interview Descriptions: Phone interview, in-person interview, reference check, and background check. Simple and easy process. HR conducted reference checks after both interviews were complete and the offer was extended one week post-interview.
Interview Questions: What do you see yourself doing in 5 years?

title: Help Desk Supervisor Interview
Application Type: I applied in-person. The process took 6 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (New York, NY)
Interview Descriptions: Long process, 3 step interview process. Informal interview onsite, formal interview and HR. I did like that they offered me the questions they would ask 15 minutes before the formal interview. I also liked that they have you meet with HR and give you paperwork showing everything from PTO to cost of insurance and so on. Very thorough process.
Interview Questions: What would you say is your favorite managerial style?

title: Receptionist Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 5 days. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Oct 2019
Interview Descriptions: I worked for the department that I majored in. I worked with great people and the folks who interviewed me were fellow professors and administrators I had known for years
Interview Questions: What was your previous work experience? What is your class schedule like?

title: Junior Software Developer Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 months. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI)
Interview Descriptions: The hiring process consisted of a phone screening followed by an on-site interview. The interview focused largely on communication style and included some semi-guided hands-on programming and conceptual problem solving.
Interview Questions: What is your preferred management style?

title: Horticulture Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Skype interview for about an hour. Asked specific horticulture questions. Very nice interviewers, and fair straightforward questions. Will be asked about how to perform horticulture tasks such as knowing when a plant is dry, etc.
Interview Questions: How do you prune a plant?

title: Research Fellow Interview
Application Type: I applied through other source. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Met with the professor and discussed my previous research experience. The professor was very cordial, open to my suggestions and encouraged me to ask questions. Overall, the interview process was very smooth and I really enjoyed it!
Interview Questions: Asked me to describe my previous research experience

title: Administrative Coordinator - IT Department Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Jul 2019
Interview Descriptions:
I has a phone interview at the UW-School of Public Health and Medicine. I was to have a phone interview with one person but the interview was with a completely different person than what was scheduled.

The interview was very brief, not personal at all. Not even small talk at the beginning or end. The interviewer seemed like she was reading off of a list of questions as she was counting as she was asking them. When I asked questions about the team or the work environment, she did not seem to know and was stumbling to answer. It was a little off-putting.
Interview Questions: How  do you prioritize your work load?

title: Intern - Hourly Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: Interview was easy going and staff was friendly. All the questions they asked me were easy to answer and I felt knowledgable with my answers. The interview was short, but I felt like we covered everything needed.
Interview Questions: They asked me about my experience.

title: Laboratory Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied through college or university. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: The post-doc who posted the position interviewed me. I was rejected for that specific job but was offered a similar position working under a different researcher in the lab. Because it was for a simple student lab worker job, the interview was straightforward.
Interview Questions: What are three words you would use to describe yourself?

title: Administrative Assistant Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 2 weeks. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Jun 2019
Interview Descriptions: Brief Interview after submitting resume with cover letter. I interviewed with friendly and open-minded people that I knew would be fun to work with. Glad that I was able to work for the University, even through my time there was cut short due to personal issues.
Interview Questions: Tell me about your self

title: Research Lead Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: It started with a phone screening interview. Shortly afterwards it was followed by an in-person one-on-one interview with the head of the project and interview with the team on the same day.
Interview Questions: Preferred analysis software

title: Postdoctoral Fellow Interview
Application Type: I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison
Interview Descriptions: I was in a lucky position because I know the lab and the supervisor before, so I only had a Skype interview (while I was on a train). But other hired post-docs went through rigid interview processes, like campus visit, research presentation, chatting with almost everyone in the lab
Interview Questions: What is your career plan in the next 5 years?

title: Lab Technician Interview
Application Type: I applied online. The process took 1 week. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in May 2019
Interview Descriptions:
1) General In-Person Interview (Behavioral and Skills related questions)
2) On-site trip to the lab
3) Communicating with Lab Technicians and RAs
4) Final Interview about the on-site trip (Questions about thoughts about the lab and what you are planning to do when working there)
Interview Questions: What are some skills you can do with your hands?

title: Associate Scientist Interview

title: Assistant Vice Provost (Assistant Vice Chancellor) Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Jun 2018
Interview Descriptions:
My experience was truly awful, as there was discernible toxicity, opacity, microaggressions and general lack of professionalism that was by design and/or default.  Since I was accustomed to administrative searches and had chaired/served on search committees myself, I knew that this behavior portended that the interview was merely a perfunctory exercise.  

The position which I sought was technically not vacant, as the post-holder, who was serving in this capacity on an interim basis, had been seconded from another campus department several months before with her previous post advertised soon thereafter.  While this person had simply been designated as Assistant Vice Provost on the division’s website, I discovered between my Skype and in-person interviews through a non-university publication that she and another AVP were serving ad interim.  Nonetheless, I decided to visit Madison for continuous learning purposes.

My interview commenced around noon with only three committee members.  The questions that they posed were fair enough and my presentation, which was lightly attended, ensued thereafter.  In my humble opinion, the question to which I responded during my presentation basically asked me how I would represent the Vice Provost across campus.  I decided to be a bit more intentional by focusing on processes, stakeholders and possible innovations during my talk.  Not too long after I started my presentation, the newly-hired Chief of Staff  (COS) walked out; his face had evinced disgust throughout his stay.  I ignored this petulant behavior, completed my presentation and was taken to the Vice Provost's office for a meeting.

After having sat in a chair outside his office for a while, the COS, without introducing himself or apologizing for leaving my presentation, abruptly moved me to an ante-room elsewhere; there was a confidential meeting being held in the adjoining conference room and a large sign to this effect was placed on the door.  My meeting with the Vice Provost was ok, despite subtle comments/hints that betrayed his lack of interest in my candidacy. My last meeting for the day, comprising two Assistant Vice Provosts (one of whom was permanent) and the Chief of Staff, was extremely hostile; the permanent AVP at one point told me not to expect that I would act there like I did at two other research institutions with which I had been affiliated.  For his part, the COS did not disappoint; after I had answered an open-ended question, he rolled his eyes, looked at the clock and told me that I should keep my responses short.  I smiled, apologized and noted that I would be succinct henceforth; the other interim AVP told me not to apologize and I said that it (apologizing) was a practice that was not alien to me (she later walked away without saying goodbye).  Later the COS, who had been tasked with taking me back to my hotel, told me with disdain that because it was raining, he would have someone else take me. 

The lack of transparency and accompanying treatment that was meted out to me were appalling but deliberate.  There were trivial but revealing slights such as not being collected from or driven to the airport, selecting my only meal there (lunch) from Panera’s website, paying for my room at a university-owned property and later having the gracious man at the desk fix the ‘problem’ and waiting approximately 3 months to obtain a refund for travel-related expenses with every excuse deployed for the tardiness.  I also was asked to complete a background check before my arrival because they wanted to 'proceed quickly'; this was another blatant red flag that I chose to ignore in the moment.  At a minimum, I ought to have commenced the background check, if at all, after the in-person interview.  They phoned my references the day after my interview (all of them contacted me promptly and specified who called and what was discussed) and the post was offered to the interim AVP.

In closing, I know that the intent of everyone (almost?) in the diversity division during my visit was to ensure that their ‘friend’ formally got ‘her’ job.  Notwithstanding, I was surprised that the visit of an outsider like myself could engender so much derision and condescension, while the division concomitantly claimed to be the conscience of the university on diversity-related matters.  The irony of this dissonance was not lost on me, while accepting the fact that people rationalize who is deserving of respect based on the exigencies of the moment and their parochial interests.  Given the division’s (and perhaps the institution) nonchalance, penchant for nepotism and palpable toxicity, this place would not have been a good fit for me anyway.  One other proviso that is worth bearing in mind: your account and its contents would only be deleted six years after the post for which you applied had been filled.  I know because I got a specific answer from HR only after much probing.
Interview Questions: The Skype questions portended a great deal of angst in the division and addressed the manner in which the AVP would assuage the concerns of staff members.  In addition, there were the usual questions regarding previous experiences and roles

title: Communications Specialist Interview
Application Type: I applied online. I interviewed at University of Wisconsin-Madison (Madison, WI) in Aug 2017
Interview Descriptions: I applied online and 2 weeks later was invited to participate in a phone interview with 4 university staff and faculty members. 2 weeks after the phone interview, I was invited to campus for an in-person interview. I was emailed instructions in advance to design a communications strategy presentation that I'd have to deliver to 15+ department members. The entire interview lasted 3 hours: interview with 4 staff members, presentation to department and interview with department directors. Overall, this interview was a negative experience for me due to the long interview process and the fact that candidates were asked to design an entire communications strategy to present to a large group. Designing a customized strategy takes time, effort and skill - something that I get paid to do in my every day profession was provided free of charge to this department. Frankly, I do not like consulting with a group that is going to most likely take those innovative ideas and concepts that I shared with them to better their operations, but not hire me for the role. After the campus interview, it took the director 3 weeks to let me know in an email that he is "sorry to bring bad news,  but they selected someone else for the position". I just find it disappointing that candidates are expected to bring their "A" game to an interview that is 3 hours long - just to be rejected 3 weeks later. It would be a little better if you could deliver a decision in a week or two weeks tops given the level of effort you expect from the candidates.
Interview Questions: The panelists asked long, behavioral questions with 2, sometimes 3 parts to the question - making it a somewhat difficult to stay on track with a thoughtful response.
